The heat in Perth that afternoon was a physical presence, a thick, wavering curtain of shimmering air that clung to the skin like a damp wool blanket. It wasn't just hot; it was a solid thing, a weight pressing down from a sky the colour of bleached bone. In the small, scorched patch of grass he called a backyard, Baz O’Connell sat on a white plastic chair that groaned under his frame, a bead of sweat tracing a slow, deliberate path from his temple down the hard line of his jaw. The world smelled of baked concrete and the faint, salty promise of the ocean, a promise that the Fremantle Doctor would eventually arrive to offer its weak, afternoon reprieve. For now, though, there was just the heat and the low, contented hum of a city simmering under the sun.

Then his phone, lying face-up on the rickety patio table, buzzed with a ferocity that seemed to violate the lethargy of the day. He squinted at the unknown number, an Eastern States area code, and felt a familiar jolt, a surge of something that was half-anxiety, half-electric hope. He snatched it up, his thumb swiping across the screen. "Baz here." His voice was a low rumble, conditioned by years of shouting over the din of construction sites.

"Am I speaking with Mr. Barry O'Connell?" The voice on the other end was crisp, formal, a woman's voice that sounded like it was wearing a freshly pressed suit.

"Yeah, that's me. Who's this?"

"This is Janice from the board of the Australian Pie Association. I'm calling to officially congratulate you, Mr. O'Connell. Your performance in the Western Australian regional qualifier has earned you a place. You are one of the six finalists who will be competing in the National Golden Crust Championship next month in Melbourne."

The world stopped. The oppressive heat, the buzzing of a persistent fly, the distant rumble of traffic on the highway—it all dissolved into a silent, perfect vacuum. A slow grin stretched across Baz’s face, a wide, triumphant baring of teeth that crinkled the sun-weathered skin around his eyes. He stood up so fast the plastic chair screeched back and nearly toppled over. He pumped a fist into the thick, unmoving air. "You're kidding me. The final? For real?"

"Quite real, Mr. O'Connell. A formal invitation and travel itinerary will be emailed to you within the hour. Congratulations again. And may the best man win."

The line clicked dead. Baz stared at the phone for a long moment, the screen gone dark, reflecting his own dumbstruck, ecstatic face. The final. The Golden Crust. He’d done it. He let out a roar that was pure, unadulterated joy, a primal sound that sent a flock of galahs screeching from the neighbour's gum tree. This was it. This was more than just a laugh, more than a weird hobby his brother teased him about. It was a monument to glorious, pointless ambition, and he, Baz O'Connell, scaffolder and dreamer, was one of its chief architects. He strode to the rusty old fridge he kept on the patio, pulled out a cold beer, and cracked it open with a satisfying hiss. The first gulp was victory itself, cold and sharp and tasting of a future paved with flaky pastry.

His first thought, after the initial wave of euphoria began to recede into a deep, thrumming satisfaction, was of Leo. He had to tell Leo. His younger brother, the sensible one, the one who’d gone to uni and got a proper job in an office with air conditioning and pot plants. Leo, who called Baz’s passion “structured gluttony” and worried about his cholesterol with a sincerity that was both irritating and endearing. Leo would sigh, he would lecture, but underneath it all, he would be proud. He had to be. Baz thumbed through his contacts, his hands, usually so steady on steel beams twenty storeys up, feeling a little shaky. He pressed the call button next to 'Leo the Nerd' and put the phone to his ear.

It rang twice. "Hey, big fella," Leo's voice came through, tinny and distant, punctuated by the unmistakable sound of road noise. "On your fifth beer of the arvo already?"

"Just cracked the first, you cheeky bugger. And it's a celebration," Baz boomed. "You are talking to a national finalist."

There was a pause, just a beat of static and wind. "Finalist for what? Biggest Bloke on Site?"

"The Golden Crust, dickhead! The pie-eating final! They just called. I'm in. I'm flying to Melbourne next month to eat for the title."

He could almost hear Leo shaking his head, could picture the fond, exasperated smile. "Jesus, Baz. You actually did it. You absolute madman. I thought you were just doing it to get a free feed at the local heats."

"Nah, mate, I'm serious about this. I'm the best. Now I get to prove it."

"The best at unhinging your jaw like a python? It's a noble pursuit," Leo said, the sound of his indicator clicking in the background. "Look, mate, that's… it's something, alright. We'll have to have a proper celebration when I get back."

"Where you headed, anyway?" Baz asked, taking another swig of his beer.

"Just gotta shoot down to Mandurah. Pick up some documents for work. Some old client who still thinks email is black magic. I should be back in Perth before sundown." There was a rustle, a sound of distraction. "Shit, this exit... Look, Baz, I'm proud of you, you idiot. Seriously. Don't… don't have a heart attack before the main event, eh? We'll talk tonight."

"Yeah, you too. Just watch the road, mate. Don't text and drive."

"I'm on hands-free, Mum," Leo laughed. "Talk later."

The line went dead. Baz lowered the phone, a wide, easy smile still on his face. He felt invincible. The world was his oyster, or better yet, his meat pie. He finished his beer in two long swallows and went inside, the cool of the house a sudden shock. In the kitchen, sitting on the counter, was his secret weapon. It was a pie from the small, artisan bakery downtown that he'd identified as having the closest pastry density and filling viscosity to the official contest pies. He’d been studying them, training with them. This wasn’t just about a big stomach; it was a science. It was about heat management, about finding the rhythm of crust and filling, the interplay of texture, the precise moment to swallow to conserve energy.

He picked it up. It was heavy, a perfect golden disc, still faintly warm. The scent of it—rich, dark gravy, slow-braised beef, a hint of black pepper and thyme—was the smell of his purpose. He set it down, his focus narrowing. The call from Leo had been good, but the distraction had been there in his brother's voice. That was the problem with the real world, the world of jobs and freeways and responsibilities. It was so damn distracting. His world, for the next month, had to be pure. It had to be about the pie.

His training regimen was a thing of quiet, monastic dedication. Early morning runs along the Swan River, not for fitness, but to expand his lung capacity, to teach his body to process oxygen more efficiently under duress. Hours spent chewing a specialised rubber block to strengthen his jaw muscles, an exercise that made him look like a demented bulldog to anyone who happened to glance into his living room. And the water loading. Litres and litres of water to stretch his stomach, a slow, uncomfortable process that left him feeling bloated and miserable but was essential for making the space he’d need. He was a machine being calibrated for a single, absurdly specific task. A high-performance athlete whose sport nobody respected, least of all the man he most wanted to impress.

As the afternoon bled into evening, the fierce white heat of the day softened into a golden glow. The Fremantle Doctor finally made its presence known, a cool, salty breeze that rustled the leaves of the struggling lemon tree in the corner of his yard and carried the distant sound of children playing. The initial high of the phone call had settled into a low, simmering excitement. He kept checking his phone, expecting a follow-up text from Leo, probably a link to an article about the dangers of processed meats. He was waiting for the 'I'm home' call, the promise of a shared beer and a proper ribbing.

The sun was a fiery orange smudge on the horizon when the phone rang again. He grinned, assuming it was Leo, ready with a smart-arse comment. He picked it up without checking the number. "Alright, nerd, you home yet?"

A woman's voice answered, and it was not Leo's. It was calm, professional, and utterly devoid of warmth. It was a voice that chilled the balmy evening air. "Am I speaking to a Mr. Barry O'Connell?"

"Yeah," Baz said, his grin faltering. The similarity to the call from the pie association was unnerving. "Who's this?"

"My name is Constable Davies. I'm calling from Peel Health Campus. We have your brother, Leo O'Connell, here. There's been an accident. A motor vehicle collision on the Kwinana Freeway."

The world, which had stopped so beautifully just a few hours ago, stopped again. But this time it was not a silent, perfect vacuum. This time it was a screech of tearing metal, a cacophony of shattering glass, a sickening, final thud. The plastic cup of water he’d been holding slipped from his suddenly nerveless fingers. It didn't shatter, just hit the worn linoleum with a dull thud, the water splashing over his bare feet, cold as ice.

"Is he…?" The words wouldn't form. His throat was a knot of tight muscle.

"He's alive," the constable said, and Baz's knees almost buckled in relief. But she wasn't finished. "He's alive, but his injuries are very serious, Mr. O'Connell. The doctors are with him now. They said you should come as soon as you can."

The drive south was a blur of red tail-lights and the ghostly white glare of overhead lamps smearing across the windscreen. Baz’s old ute, usually a comforting, rumbling beast, felt like a fragile cage hurtling through a hostile world. He gripped the steering wheel so hard his knuckles were white, his big frame crammed into the driver’s seat, feeling for the first time in his life not powerful, but sickeningly, terrifyingly small. The Kwinana Freeway stretched out before him, a ribbon of dark asphalt that had, just hours ago, been the site of his brother's undoing. Every passing car was a potential missile, every lane change a new threat. The city simmered no longer; it snarled.

He couldn’t stop replaying their last conversation. Leo’s laugh, tinny and distant, echoing in his memory. *I'm on hands-free, Mum.* The casual, affectionate mockery. *Don't have a heart attack before the main event, eh?* Baz’s jaw clenched so tight a bolt of pain shot up into his temple. The main event. He’d been so full of it, so wrapped up in his ridiculous, gravy-soaked dream. He had boomed about being a national finalist while his brother, the sensible one, the one who looked out for him, was driving into a nightmare. The shame was a physical sensation, a hot, coiling thing in his gut that was worse than any pre-contest bloat.

The email from the Pie Association would be in his inbox now. A formal invitation. An itinerary. A flight to Melbourne. The thought was so absurd, so obscene, that he let out a short, harsh bark of a laugh that sounded more like a sob. The Golden Crust. A monument to glorious, pointless ambition. He saw it clearly now, stripped of all its self-congratulatory romance. It was just pointless. A stupid, childish game he played while real life, fragile and precious, was happening all around him, ready to be snatched away without warning. He felt a violent urge to take his phone, the source of both his triumph and his terror, and hurl it out of the window into the rushing darkness.

Peel Health Campus rose out of the suburban dark, a modern, sterile block of beige brick and illuminated glass. It looked like any other building, but tonight it felt like a temple of dread. He parked the ute crookedly in a bay, the front wheel bumping up onto the curb, and didn't bother to fix it. The air outside was cooler now, the sea breeze more pronounced, but he barely felt it. The automatic doors of the Emergency Department slid open with a soft whoosh, releasing a gust of air that smelled of disinfectant and quiet desperation. The brightly lit waiting room was sparsely populated with the walking wounded and their worried companions, a tableau of late-night misery.

He strode to the reception desk, a monolith of pale laminate under the harsh fluorescent lights. A nurse with tired eyes looked up from her computer screen.
"I'm here to see my brother," Baz said, his voice a raw, tight thing that was barely recognisable as his own. "Leo O'Connell. There was a car accident. Someone called me."
The nurse’s expression softened with a practiced, professional pity that made Baz’s skin crawl. She typed the name into her system, her fingers clicking softly on the keyboard. The sound seemed unnaturally loud in the hushed room. "Yes, Mr. O'Connell. He's here. He's in surgery at the moment. If you'd like to take a seat, the doctor will be out to speak with you as soon as they can."

Surgery. The word landed like a punch to the stomach. It wasn't a broken arm or a few stitches. It was deep, internal, a place where things could go irrevocably wrong. He found an empty chair in a designated waiting area, a small, grim alcove with faded art on the walls and a television silently flashing a news report. A woman across from him was weeping softly into a handful of tissues. A man sat staring at the floor, his leg jiggling with a frantic, nervous energy. Baz just sat, his hands on his knees, his entire body a rigid knot of tension. The world had shrunk to this single, air-conditioned room. There was no Perth, no Melbourne, no Golden Crust. There was only the before, and the agonising, uncertain now. He stared at the swinging doors the nurse had vaguely gestured towards, willing them to open, dreading the face of the person who would eventually walk through them. Time stretched and warped, each minute an hour, each tick of the institutional clock on the wall a hammer blow against his sanity.

Finally, after an eternity carved from fear, a man in blue scrubs pushed through the doors. He was tall and weary-looking, with dark circles under his eyes that spoke of a long and difficult night. His eyes scanned the small group and settled on Baz. He walked over, his footsteps echoing on the polished floor.
"Mr. O'Connell?" the man asked, his voice low and grave. "I'm Dr. Reid. I'm one of the surgeons who has been working on your brother."
Baz stood up, his body feeling both heavy and strangely numb. He looked at the doctor's face, searching for a sign, a flicker of hope or a shadow of doom. But the man’s expression was carefully, professionally neutral.
"Can we talk for a moment in the family room? It's just over here."

The family room was a small, beige lie. It was designed to look comforting, with its soft lighting and generic watercolour prints of sailboats, but the air was thick with the ghosts of bad news. A box of tissues sat pristine on a small coffee table, a silent testament to the room’s true purpose. Baz didn’t sit. He stood in the middle of the worn carpet, his massive frame dwarfing the space, his arms hanging limp at his sides. He felt like a bull trapped in a doll’s house.

Dr. Reid gestured towards one of the chairs, but Baz didn’t seem to notice. The doctor let it go, his gaze professional and deeply tired. "Your brother was brought in with multiple traumatic injuries consistent with a high-speed collision," he began, his voice even and devoid of emotion. It was the voice of a man who had to deliver these speeches far too often. "The primary impact was on the driver's side. We took him straight to theatre. He had significant internal bleeding from a ruptured spleen, which we have managed to control, and a compound fracture of his left femur."

The words were just sounds, a medical lecture that Baz couldn't quite connect to the laughing, vibrant image of his brother. Ruptured spleen. Compound fracture. It was a foreign language describing the deconstruction of the person he knew best. He stared at a faint water stain on the ceiling, a pale brown map of some long-forgotten leak, and tried to make his brain work. He felt a strange detachment, as if he were watching a scene in a movie. This wasn't happening to him. This wasn't happening to Leo.

"The more pressing concern," Dr. Reid continued, pulling Baz’s attention back into the sterile room, "is the head injury. He sustained a significant blow to the head, which has caused a subdural hematoma—that's a bleed on the surface of the brain. We've operated to relieve the pressure, but there is still a great deal of swelling. To give his brain the best possible chance to rest and recover, we've placed him in a medically induced coma."

Coma. The word landed and exploded, silencing the medical jargon and leaving only a ringing void. A coma. Leo was here, in this building, but he was also gone. He was asleep, but it was a sleep from which he might never wake. Baz’s throat worked, but no sound came out. The image of Leo’s face, a fond, exasperated smile as he called him a 'madman', flashed in his mind, so clear and so vivid it was like a physical blow. He swayed slightly on his feet.

"Will he…?" Baz finally managed, his voice a hoarse whisper he didn't recognise. He couldn’t finish the question. He couldn’t give voice to the worst possible outcome. "Is he going to be okay?"

The doctor’s professional mask softened for a fraction of a second, a flicker of human empathy in his exhausted eyes. "It's too early to give you a definitive prognosis, Mr. O'Connell. With brain injuries, the first twenty-four to forty-eight hours are critical. We are doing everything we can. His youth and his general good health are on his side. But he is in a very serious condition. We have to wait and see how he responds once the swelling starts to go down."

The non-answer was an answer in itself. It was a confirmation of the abyss that had just opened up at Baz’s feet. He finally felt his legs give way and he collapsed into one of the flimsy chairs, which protested with a sharp crack under his weight. He didn't care if it broke. He dropped his head into his hands, his thick fingers pressing into his temples. The smell of baked concrete and the promise of the ocean felt a lifetime away. The triumphant roar he’d let out in his backyard now seemed like a sacrilege, a boast to a cruel and indifferent god.

"He's being moved to the Intensive Care Unit now," Dr. Reid said gently. "You can see him in a little while, once he's settled. The nurses on the ward will come and get you. I'm very sorry, Mr. O'Connell." The doctor gave a slight, helpless nod and then he was gone, leaving Baz alone in the beige room. The silence that rushed in was absolute, a crushing weight that was far heavier than any summer heat. The joy of a few hours ago had been a cheap, hollow thing. This, right here, was real. This was the main event. And he had never felt less like a champion.

## Chapter 2

An hour, or maybe it was a lifetime, passed in the beige room. Baz didn't move. He simply sat, letting the silence press down on him. The world had been reduced to the thrum of the air conditioning and the frantic, useless looping of his own thoughts. The last conversation. The sound of Leo’s indicator. The pie on his kitchen counter. Each memory was a fresh turn of the knife. He was eventually retrieved by a kind-faced, middle-aged nurse named Carol, whose soft voice and gentle hand on his arm were the first touches of human kindness he had felt since the constable's call. She led him through another set of swinging doors and down a long, quiet corridor that felt different from the chaotic energy of the Emergency Department. The air here was cooler, the silence more profound, punctuated only by the soft beep and whir of unseen machines.

The Intensive Care Unit was a world unto itself. It was a place of hushed efficiency, of controlled and measured crisis. Each patient was in their own glass-walled bay, a small stage for a private drama of survival, presided over by a tangled web of technology. Monitors glowed with waterfalls of coloured lines and numbers, intravenous poles stood like metallic trees bearing bags of clear fluid, and ventilators hissed and clicked with a steady, rhythmic breath that was both life-sustaining and deeply unnatural. The smell was the same as the rest of the hospital, disinfectant and illness, but sharpened here, more concentrated, with an undercurrent of something metallic and cold.

Carol led him to a bay at the far end. "He's just in here, love. He has his own nurse with him at all times. Just press the button if you need anything at all. You can stay as long as you like."

Baz stepped into the room and his own breath hitched in his throat. The figure in the bed was and was not Leo. The familiar shape of his brother was there, the line of his shoulders under the thin hospital blanket, the dark hair splayed against the pillow. But this version of Leo was unnervingly still, his face pale and swollen, a small white bandage taped to his temple. A tube entered his mouth, secured with tape, connected to the ventilator that rose and fell in his place, forcing air into his lungs with a soft, mechanical sigh. Wires snaked from his chest to a monitor above the bed, where a green line jaggedly traced the frantic, stubborn beat of his heart.

He looked small. Leo, who had always seemed to be vibrating with a restless, intellectual energy, who was always talking, gesturing, his mind ten steps ahead of everyone else, was utterly and completely inert. All his wit, his sarcasm, his fond exasperation, was gone, replaced by the humming and beeping of the machines that were keeping his body alive. Baz felt a wave of nausea. He wanted to tear the tubes and wires away, to shake his brother awake, to demand he stop this terrible, silent prank. He took a hesitant step closer, his work boots feeling clumsy and loud on the clean floor. He reached out a hand, calloused and huge, and gently touched Leo's arm, just above the IV line. His skin was warm. That simple fact, the warmth of his brother’s body, was a small, desperate anchor in the tidal wave of horror.

He pulled a hard plastic visitor’s chair to the bedside, its legs scraping against the floor with a sound that felt like a desecration of the room’s quiet solemnity. He sat down, hunched forward, his elbows on his knees, and just watched. He watched the numbers on the screen, trying to decipher their meaning, trying to will them to be ‘good’ numbers. He watched the steady rise and fall of Leo’s chest, a puppet’s movement controlled by the machine beside him. The minutes bled into an hour, then two. The nurse, a young man named Ben, came in and out, checking readings, making notes, moving with a quiet competence that was both reassuring and terrifying. He spoke to Baz in low, respectful tones, explaining what he was doing, but the words barely registered.

Baz’s phone, forgotten in his pocket, vibrated against his leg. The buzz was a phantom of the earlier, joyful call, now a hateful intrusion. He pulled it out, his thumb clumsy on the screen. There was a new email. The subject line glowed with obscene cheerfulness: *Congratulations - Golden Crust Championship Finalist*. His vision tunnelled. The words seemed to mock him from the screen. A flight to Melbourne. A hotel reservation. A schedule of media appearances. A future that had ceased to exist. His thumb hovered over the delete icon, his whole body trembling with a mixture of rage and revulsion. He couldn’t even bring himself to do it. Deleting it felt like an action, and he was capable of none. He just switched the phone to silent and shoved it deep into his pocket, a toxic secret weighing him down.

The call to their parents was the hardest thing he had ever had to do. They had retired to a small village in the south of England five years ago, a world away in every sense. He stepped out of the ICU, back into the quiet corridor, and dialled. Hearing his mother’s cheerful, unsuspecting voice ask him how he was, how her "two wonderful boys" were doing, shattered the fragile composure he had been holding together. He choked on the words, his voice cracking as he relayed the doctor’s sterile report. The silence on the other end of the line was a vast, echoing chasm of disbelief and pain, followed by a sound, a thin, wailing cry from his mother, that would be seared into his memory forever. They were booking the first available flight. They would be there in thirty hours. Until then, he was alone.

He returned to Leo’s bedside, the weight of his parents’ grief now added to his own. He leaned in close to his brother’s ear, the smell of antiseptic sharp in his nostrils.
“You hear that, you git?” he whispered, his voice thick and rough. “You’ve gone and made Mum cry. You better not make me tell her anything worse. You better not.”
He started talking then, a low, rambling monologue to fill the awful silence. He talked about his day, about the oppressive heat, the call from the pie lady, his own stupid, selfish pride. “I was a right idiot, Leo. A proper knob. Strutting around the yard like I’d won the bloody lottery, all over a pie competition. While you were… while this was happening. I’m so sorry, mate. I’m so sorry.”
He talked about their childhood, about the time they’d tried to build a raft to sail down the Swan River and nearly drowned, about the dog they’d shared, about the first car Leo had ever bought, a beat-up Datsun he’d loved more than anything. He talked until his throat was raw, his words a desperate, continuous prayer aimed at the unmoving man in the bed. He was trying to build a bridge of sound across the silent, terrifying gap that had opened between them, hoping a single word might find its way through.

As the night deepened outside, a dinner service cart rattled past the door of the ICU. Through the glass, Baz saw a nurse deliver a tray to a visitor in another bay. On it was a plate shrouded in a metal lid. The visitor lifted it, and a small puff of steam escaped. Underneath sat a meat pie, pale and institutional, its gravy thin and leaking into a mound of instant mashed potato. A jolt went through Baz, a bizarre and instantaneous reflex. *Too much moisture in the filling. The pastry will be compromised. Soggy bottom.* The thought, a fragment of the man he had been that afternoon, was so alien, so grotesquely inappropriate, that he felt a fresh wave of self-disgust wash over him. He looked from the sad, hospital pie to his brother’s pale face, and the gulf between his old life and this new reality yawned wide and bottomless. His pointless ambition, his structured gluttony, his entire world of pastry and filling, had turned to ash in his mouth.

The first light of dawn was a sickly grey, filtering through the blinds of the ICU window and stripping the room of its nocturnal shadows. Baz hadn't slept. He sat in the same hard chair, his spine a column of agony, his clothes smelling of stale sweat and fear. Outside, he knew Perth was waking up, the early commuters starting their journeys, the city beginning to warm for another day. It was a world he no longer belonged to. His own world was four glass walls, the rhythmic hiss of the ventilator, and the jagged green line on the monitor that proved his brother was still, somehow, fighting. He was an exhausted sentry at the gate between life and death, and he had no idea which way the traffic was flowing.

A dull ache in his jaw reminded him of his training. The hours spent chewing the specialised rubber block, the single-minded focus on building strength for a task that now seemed like the definition of insanity. He had treated his body like a piece of high-performance machinery, calibrating it for the sole purpose of consuming pastry faster than anyone else. Now, that same body felt like a leaden, useless weight. The expanded lung capacity he had worked for was useless here; it was a machine breathing for Leo. The strong jaw was useless; it could not form the words to make this right. He felt like an idiot, a child who had been playing with toys while the house burned down around him, and the shame was a physical, burning presence.

Carol, the nurse from the night before, appeared at his side near mid-morning, her face etched with the same gentle exhaustion as his own. She held a styrofoam cup of coffee in one hand. "You're still here," she said, not as a question, but a statement of tired fact. "You need to get some rest, love. And some food. You'll do him no good if you collapse." She offered the coffee, but Baz just stared at it as if it were poison. The idea of consumption, of fuelling the body he now despised, was repulsive. "Can't," he mumbled, shaking his head. "I'm not hungry." The thought of food, any food, but especially the rich, savoury taste of pie, brought a fresh surge of bile to the back of his throat. His former passion was now a source of deep physical revulsion, a penance he would pay with an empty stomach and the gnawing ache of hunger.

He was staring at the drip rate of the IV bag, trying to find meaning in the slow, methodical fall of each clear drop, when his phone buzzed on the chair beside him. He ignored it. It buzzed again, insistent. Annoyed, thinking it might be a friend he didn't have the strength to talk to, he glanced at the screen. The name displayed was 'Australian Pie Association'. Janice. For a second, he felt nothing but a blank confusion, as if seeing a name from a language he no longer spoke. Then, a hot, black rage surged through him, so potent it made his vision swim. He snatched the phone, his thumb swiping across the screen, his voice a low growl. "What?" The crisp, professional voice from the day before, from another lifetime, chirped on the other end. "Mr. O'Connell? Janice from the APA. I just wanted to confirm you received our email and see if you had any initial questions about the travel arrangements for Melbourne—"

"My brother is in a coma," Baz cut her off, the words like stones in his mouth, each one a separate, heavy agony. "He's in the ICU on a ventilator because some bastard smashed into him on the freeway. So you can take your Golden Crust, and your travel arrangements, and your whole bloody pathetic competition, and you can shove it." There was a stunned, sputtering silence on the other end, the beginning of a half-formed apology that he had no intention of hearing. Baz jabbed the 'end call' button with a furious finality and dropped the phone onto the vacant part of Leo’s bed. It landed softly on the blanket, a silent, useless black rectangle. The great monument to his ambition had been officially demolished in a single, brutal sentence.

He felt no triumph in the act, no release. Just a vast, hollow emptiness where the pride and excitement used to be. He had shed his old identity, the champion pie-eater, the scaffolder with a dream. It had sloughed off him like a dead skin, leaving behind something raw and exposed. All that was left was the man sitting in the hard plastic chair. All that was left was Leo’s brother. He reached out and wrapped his huge hand around his brother's foot, the flesh beneath the thin blanket surprisingly cool. The contact was a desperate, grounding act. "It's just us now, mate," he whispered to the still figure, the sound swallowed by the hum of the machines. "Just us."

## Chapter 3

The next two days bled into one another, a monotonous grey smear of time measured in nursing shifts and the changing numbers on Leo’s monitors. Baz became part of the ward's furniture, a large, silent figure perpetually folded into the uncomfortable visitor's chair. He learned the rhythms of the ICU: the hushed early morning handover between the night and day staff, the midday doctor’s rounds, the quiet lull of the afternoon, the slow dimming of the lights as evening settled in. He spoke only when spoken to, answering the doctors’ gentle, non-committal updates with a terse nod and the nurses’ questions about his own wellbeing with a shake of his head. He was a statue of grief, rooted to the spot by a leaden combination of guilt and dread. His old life, the one filled with the roar of construction sites and the scent of baking pastry, felt like a story someone had once told him about a different person.

His body, once a finely tuned instrument of glorious, pointless ambition, was now just a source of dull, persistent pain. His back ached from the chair, a deep, grinding discomfort that he welcomed as a form of penance. Hunger was a hollow knot in his stomach, a constant reminder of his revulsion. He couldn’t bring himself to eat. The nurses, Carol and Ben, would leave sandwiches or cups of soup on the small table by the door, but he ignored them until they were quietly cleared away, untouched. The only thing he forced himself to do was drink the water they brought him, a grim parody of his old training regimen. He would swallow the cold, tasteless liquid, feeling it fill his empty stomach not to stretch it for a competition, but simply to keep his body from shutting down completely. It was a mechanical act of self-preservation for which he felt no motivation beyond a primal instinct he couldn't quite extinguish.

On the third day, his phone, which he now kept on silent, lit up with a call from 'Mick the Mouth', his site foreman. For a moment, Baz just stared at it, the name a relic from a buried civilisation. He finally answered, stepping out into the corridor so his voice wouldn't disturb the ward’s sacred quiet. "Yeah," he grunted. "Baz, mate, where the hell are you?" Mick’s voice boomed, full of gravel and worksite bonhomie. "The lads are asking. You didn't show Monday, or yesterday. Everything alright? Pull a sickie and get lost on the piss?" The casual assumption, so normal just a week ago, was now a profound insult. "It's my brother," Baz said, his voice flat and dead. "He's in hospital. Bad car accident." The line went quiet. Mick’s tone, when he spoke again, was different, stripped of its usual bluster. "Jesus, Baz. I'm sorry, mate. Shit. Is he… how is he?" Baz recited the sterile litany—ICU, coma, head injury—with the tired precision of a man who had said the words too many times to himself. "Look, mate, you just stay there," Mick said, his voice earnest. "Don't you worry about work. I'll sort the roster. Just… you call me if you need anything. Anything at all, you hear?" Baz hung up without replying, the offer of help feeling like it was coming from across an ocean. He was in a lifeboat with Leo, and everyone else was on a distant shore.

When the suffocating quiet of Leo's room became too much, he would pace the corridors or sit in the main waiting area, a purgatory of uncomfortable chairs and outdated magazines. He started to recognise the other silent, haunted figures who shared his vigil. There was a young woman with purple-dyed hair who was always there, endlessly scrolling through pictures on her phone, her face a mask of numb despair. There was an older Italian couple who would arrive every morning with a small bag of food and sit holding hands, praying softly with a rosary. They never spoke to each other, this small, fractured community of watchers, but a silent understanding passed between them in weary, sidelong glances. They were all members of the same terrible club, initiated by a late-night phone call and bound by the hum and beep of life-sustaining machines.

The messages from his father tracked the agonisingly slow journey from the other side of the world. *Landed in Dubai. 6 hour layover.* *Boarding for Perth now. See you soon, son.* Each text was a small explosion of anxiety in Baz’s chest. He had been alone in his grief, cocooned in the sterile bubble of the ICU. Soon he would have to share it. He would have to witness his mother's raw pain and his father's stoic, crumbling façade. He would have to be the strong one, the one who had been on the ground, the one who knew the doctors' names and the nursing shifts. He found himself dreading their arrival almost as much as he craved it, the thought of their collective sorrow in one small room feeling like a weight that could crush them all.

An hour before they were due to arrive from the airport, Baz went into the small public bathroom near the waiting area. He splashed his face with cold water, the shock of it doing little to wake him from his stupor. He stared at his reflection in the cheap, steel-framed mirror and barely recognised the man looking back. His normally sun-browned face was pale and sallow, his eyes bloodshot and sunk deep into their sockets, ringed with dark purple smudges of exhaustion. A rough, patchy beard was invading the hard line of his jaw. He looked hollowed out, a ghost haunting his own skin. He thought of the triumphant, roaring man in the sun-scorched backyard, the man who had tasted a future paved with flaky pastry, and felt a bitter, empty laugh rise in his throat. That man was gone, maybe forever. He took a deep, shuddering breath, straightened his shoulders, and tried to arrange his features into a mask of grim competence. His parents would need him to be solid. He had to be the rock. The main event was about to begin.

He saw them through the glass of the automatic doors before they saw him. They looked smaller than he remembered, and infinitely more fragile, as if the twenty-four-hour flight had aged them a decade. His mother, Mary, was leaning on his father’s arm, her face a pale, crumpled mask of anxiety. His father, Frank, stood ramrod straight, but the effort of it was visible in the tight set of his jaw and the deep lines etched around his eyes. The doors hissed open and they saw him. His mother let out a small, wounded sound and rushed forward, her embrace a desperate, clinging thing that spoke of terror and a frantic need for reassurance. Baz wrapped his arms around her thin, trembling frame, smelling the faint, recycled air of the airplane cabin on her coat, and felt a fresh crack appear in his own fragile composure.

Frank followed, placing a heavy hand on Baz’s shoulder. His own hug was brief and awkward, the stiff embrace of a man who used actions, not affection, to express his love. "Barry," he said, his voice raspy from the dry cabin air. He cleared his throat, his eyes scanning his son's face, taking in the exhaustion and despair. "The doctor… what's the latest?" The question was direct, a demand for facts in a situation that defied logic, a desperate attempt to find a solid handhold in a landslide of emotion. Baz’s own words felt like they were dredged from the bottom of a well. He recited the cold facts—the surgery, the hematoma, the induced coma—his voice a monotone that barely disturbed the air.

"This way," Baz said finally, his voice sounding hollow to his own ears. He led them from the relative chaos of the main waiting room down the quiet, sterile corridor that had become his entire world. With each step, he could feel their dread mounting, mirroring the terror he had felt on his own first journey down this hall. He was the unwilling tour guide to the worst moment of their lives, and the responsibility was suffocating. He paused outside the glass wall of Leo’s bay, taking a deep breath before he had to present his broken brother to his parents, steeling himself for the impact it would have.

He pushed the door open. Mary’s hand flew to her mouth, and a strangled sob escaped, a sound of pure maternal agony that cut through the clinical beeping of the machines. She took a few stumbling steps towards the bed, her eyes fixed on Leo’s still, pale face, the tube, the wires. "Oh, my boy," she whispered, her voice shattering. "My baby boy." She reached out a trembling hand but hesitated, as if afraid to touch him, to confirm the reality of it. Frank stood frozen in the doorway, his face ashen. The rigid control he had maintained dissolved, leaving behind a raw, naked pain that was more shocking than any tears. He stared at his younger son, the one who had gone to uni, the one with the bright future, now reduced to a collection of vital signs on a glowing screen. The sight seemed to rob him of breath, of strength, of hope.

"The machine breathes for him," Baz heard himself say, his voice a detached monotone. "It helps his body rest. The doctor said the swelling in his brain is the main thing. We just… we have to wait for it to go down." The words were a script he had learned by heart, and reciting them now, to his parents, felt like a betrayal. He was explaining the mechanics of the tragedy, sanitising the horror. He felt his father’s hand on his back, a brief, steadying pressure. Frank had moved to Mary's side, guiding her gently into the chair Baz had vacated. She finally reached out and took Leo’s hand, her fingers wrapping around his, her other hand stroking his hair, murmuring to him in a low, continuous stream of love and encouragement, as if her voice alone could call him back from the silent depths.

Frank pulled another chair over, and for a long moment, the three of them simply sat, a silent, grieving tableau united by the rhythmic hiss of the ventilator. The arrival of his parents had changed the room’s atmosphere. It was no longer just Baz’s private hell; it was a shared family catastrophe. After what felt like an eternity, Frank turned his gaze from Leo to his older son. He took in Baz's ragged appearance for the first time—the sunken eyes, the stubble, the way his large frame seemed to have shrunk inside his clothes. "Son," he said, his voice low and firm. "You look like hell. When did you last eat something?" The question, so simple and paternal, landed with the force of a physical blow. Baz just shook his head, unable to speak. The thought of food was still a violation. "We're going to the cafeteria," Frank stated, not a suggestion but a command. "You and me. Your mother will stay with him. You're no good to anyone like this." He stood up, a quiet, unshakeable authority radiating from him. For the first time in days, someone was telling Baz what to do, and the tired, broken part of him found he hadn't the strength to resist.

The hospital cafeteria at night was a starkly-lit pocket of soulless functionality. The air smelled of burnt coffee and floor polish, a thin, unappetizing aroma that did nothing to stir the appetite. Frank navigated the short, empty queue with a grim purpose, returning with two plastic trays. On each was a plate bearing a dry-looking chicken schnitzel, a scoop of pale mashed potato, and a scattering of overcooked peas. He placed one in front of Baz and sat down opposite him, his movements economical and deliberate. “Eat,” he commanded, picking up his own knife and fork.

Baz stared at the plate. The food looked alien, an obscene offering in the face of his brother's silent battle upstairs. The schnitzel’s breaded coating was the colour of sawdust, a pale mockery of the golden-brown pastry that had once been the centre of his universe. The thought made him feel sick. He pushed the tray away slightly, the plastic legs scraping on the linoleum. "I can't, Dad."

Frank put his cutlery down with a sharp clatter that made Baz flinch. He leaned forward, his gaze intense and unwavering. “Your mother is up there, falling to pieces. Leo is fighting for his life. And you are sitting here, starving yourself like a bloody martyr. Who does that help, Barry? Does it help Leo? Does it help your mother? Does it help you?” He jabbed a finger towards the plate. “It helps no one. So you will pick up that fork, you will cut that piece of chicken, and you will put it in your mouth. You will do it because I am telling you to. And you will do it because you need to be strong for them. We don't have the luxury of falling apart. Not yet.”

The words were hard, brutal, and exactly what Baz needed to hear. They were a slap in the face, a violent jolt back to the world of the living. Shamed by the truth in his father's logic, Baz slowly pulled the tray back. His hands felt clumsy, his movements stiff, as if he were re-learning how to use his own body. He picked up the fork, the metal cool and heavy in his hand. He cut a small piece of the schnitzel and lifted it to his mouth. The texture was dry and tough, the taste was nothing, but he forced himself to chew, to swallow. It felt like swallowing sand. He took another bite, and then another, the mechanical action a form of obedience.

They ate in silence for several minutes. Frank seemed to sense that the spell of Baz’s self-imposed fast was broken and did not push him further. Finally, his father put down his fork, his own plate half-eaten. “Now,” he said, his voice softer but no less firm. “Tell me about your day. The day it happened. Not just the accident. The whole thing.”

Baz kept his eyes fixed on the sad collection of peas remaining on his plate. He didn’t want to revisit it, to give voice to the joy that now felt like a terrible sin. But his father’s unwavering gaze demanded it. So he began. He spoke of the suffocating heat, the lethargy of the afternoon, and then the first phone call. He described the woman's crisp voice, the shock, the wild, pure elation of hearing he had made the final. He recounted his roar of triumph, the cold victory of the first beer, the feeling of invincibility. He forced himself to say the name out loud, a name that felt blasphemous in this sterile, hopeless place. "The Golden Crust Championship," he mumbled, his voice thick with shame. "It's… it was a professional pie-eating competition."

He braced himself for his father’s reaction: a shake of the head, a dismissive sigh, a look of disappointment that his eldest son’s greatest ambition was so profoundly absurd. And so Baz told him. He told him everything. Not the heroic version, not the legend that was forming around the trophy, but the real, ugly, painful truth. He spoke of the desperate, one-sided deal he had made in the dead of night, of the brutal runs along the river, of the force-feeding sessions in the lonely kitchen, of his father standing over him with a stopwatch. The wild, desperate energy that had propelled Baz across the country had finally found its destination, not in a winner's circle under television lights, but here, in the quiet humility of a hospital room, in his brother's clear and grateful eyes. High above the city, balancing on a steel beam with the wind whistling past, he felt more grounded than he had in months. Several months later, the fierce heat of summer had finally broken, giving way to the gentle, balmy evenings of early autumn. In the small, scorched patch of grass he called a backyard, Baz O’Connell sat on a white plastic chair that no longer groaned under his frame. Leo took the bottle, his grip steady, a thin white scar barely visible on his temple. He still walked with a slight limp, a permanent reminder of the Kwinana Freeway, but he was here. He was whole. He looked around the small yard, at the rickety table, at the struggling lemon tree, at the man sitting beside him. This was his monument. Not the ridiculous gold-plated pie gathering dust on a mantelpiece, but this. This simple, fragile, and unbreakable reality. This was the glorious, pointless ambition, and he, Baz O’Connell, scaffolder and brother, was its chief architect. And it was more than enough.

## Chapter 9

He descended in the rattling cage of the worksite lift, the city rising up to meet him as he went down. Standing beside the corrugated iron shed that served as the site office was a woman who was so out of place she seemed to have been digitally inserted into the scene. Her blonde hair was pulled back in a severe, elegant style, and she held a slim leather portfolio clutched in one hand. As Baz approached, his massive frame casting a long shadow over her, she turned, and a bright, professional smile clicked into place. It didn’t reach her eyes, which were a cool, assessing blue. "Mr. O'Connell? Baz? I’m Chloe Vance. I'm a producer with Channel Nine. Thank you for coming down."

I'm done with it."

He thought of the drab, underfunded physiotherapy room, the worn-out equipment, the overworked nurses and therapists who had patiently, painstakingly pieced his brother back together. He thought of the other patients on the ward, the stroke victims and the accident survivors, all fighting their own quiet, desperate battles. The world, with its complicated demands and its terrible bargains, had found him again.

The world seemed to tilt on its axis, the familiar noise of the worksite fading into a dull, distant roar. Fifty thousand dollars. It wasn't a number; it was a tangible thing. It was the new set of parallel bars the physio, an overworked woman named Brenda, had said they desperately needed. It was the upgraded pulley system for limb strengthening. It was salaries, resources, and relief for the very people who had dragged Leo back from the silent abyss. Chloe Vance hadn’t just offered a donation; she had presented him with the full weight of his gratitude and his conscience. He looked from her pristine, expensive shoes standing on the dusty, oil-stained ground to the half-finished building behind her, a monument to commerce, and felt the simple certainties of his life begin to crumble.

"My brother makes his own decisions," Baz finally managed, his voice a low, rough growl. "This isn't just about me." Chloe’s professional smile remained fixed, but a flicker of victory registered in her cool blue eyes. She knew she had him. She slid a sleek, cream-coloured business card from her portfolio, holding it out between two fingers. The card was thick and heavy, a different species from the flimsy paper rectangles passed around on the worksite. "Of course," she said smoothly. "Talk to him. But the offer is time-sensitive. The rest of the afternoon passed in a haze. The familiar, dangerous work of balancing on high steel, of guiding tons of metal into place, usually demanded his full, unwavering attention, but today his mind was elsewhere. He was back in the rehabilitation ward, a place of quiet, stubborn effort and the pervasive smell of disinfectant. He saw the faded posters on the wall, the worn linoleum floor, the shared equipment that was constantly in use. He saw the faces of the other patients—the elderly man recovering from a stroke, patiently trying to stack plastic cups; the young woman in the wheelchair, her face a mask of frustration as she fought to regain movement in her legs. They were all there, fighting their quiet wars. He had won his absurd battle and received his golden prize. Theirs was a longer, harder, and far more significant fight, waged in obscurity and with limited resources.

That evening, in the familiar sanctuary of the backyard, the ritual felt different. The air was still and cool, the beer was cold, but a new tension hung between the two brothers. Baz watched Leo take a long swallow from his bottle, his movements still careful but now imbued with a casual confidence that had been absent for months. He had put on some weight, and the haunted, hollowed-out look was gone from his eyes, replaced by his old, familiar light. He was healing. He was becoming himself again. He delivered the details with a palpable distaste, describing the producer and her proposal as if he were handling something foul. This was the moment. Baz stared into the amber depths of his beer bottle, unable to meet his brother's eye. "I was going to," he said, his voice quiet. "And then she mentioned the other part of the deal. They want to make a donation to the Royal Perth rehab ward. In our name." He paused, letting the silence stretch. "Fifty thousand dollars, Leo." The laughter died on Leo's lips. The backyard, with its chirping crickets and the distant rumble of traffic, fell completely silent. The number, so stark and significant, changed the very nature of the conversation, stripping away the sarcasm and leaving behind a complex, uncomfortable reality. Leo was no longer smiling. His gaze became distant, his eyes unfocused, and Baz knew, with a painful certainty, exactly where his brother's mind had gone. He was back on the ward, not as a patient in a bed, but as an observer, seeing the place with his newly recovered clarity.

He was seeing Brenda, the physio, taping up the frayed handle on a rowing machine because there was no budget for a new one. He knew, better than Baz ever could, exactly what that money would mean.

## Chapter 10

I was mostly preoccupied with the fact that my entire body felt like a single, comprehensive bruise and I had a desperate, primal urge for a glass of water." He paused, looking at her with polite inquiry. "The trophy came later. As I mentioned, it's quite gaudy."

A flicker of annoyance crossed Chloe’s face before being professionally suppressed. She turned to Baz, hoping to find more fertile ground. "Baz, that power, that drive. We see it as a physical manifestation of your love. When you were there, in your kitchen, forcing down pie after pie, pushing your body to the absolute limit… what was the one image, the one thought, that kept you going through the pain?" Her question was a baited hook, dangling the promise of a tearful, emotional confession. Baz stared at the camera lens nearest him, its red light a malevolent eye. He thought not of a single image, but of the whole grinding, nauseating process. He thought of the revulsion, the bloating, the sheer, bloody-minded will required. He translated it all into his own language, stripping it bare of all poetry. "Just had to get the numbers up," he said, his voice a low, flat rumble. "It was a training exercise. You set a target, you hit the target. That's all."

"But *why*?" Chloe pressed, her voice taking on a sharper edge of frustration. "Why that target? Why that specific, gruelling method?" Baz shifted his massive frame in the too-small armchair. He was a bull in a doll's house, and he was beginning to feel cornered. "Seemed like the right kind of price to pay," he grunted, the words an admission he hadn't intended to make, a brief, unguarded glimpse into the desperate, magical thinking that had possessed him. Chloe seized on it, her eyes lighting up. "A price! So you did see it as a kind of bargain, a sacrifice you were making to some higher power, to the universe itself, for your brother's life?" Her voice was triumphant, she had her soundbite.

Before Baz could retreat back into his stony silence, Leo leaned forward, intervening with the calm, precise timing of a chess master. "Chloe, I think you're mistaking a psychological coping mechanism for a theological treatise," he said, his voice still gentle but now carrying a sharp, analytical edge. "My brother, faced with a situation of complete powerlessness, created a task over which he had absolute control. He manufactured a private, brutal ordeal in order to feel like he was doing *something* in a situation where nothing could be done. It's a common response to trauma. I believe it's referred to as a 'focal substitution'." He looked at Baz, then back at Chloe. "It was less about bargaining with the universe and more about my brother finding a way to not go completely insane. A fact for which I'm eternally grateful, but it's probably not the heroic narrative you're looking for."

Chloe’s face was a mask of barely controlled fury. Her "narrative beats" were being systematically dismantled, her emotional core exposed as a clinical case study. She was losing, and she knew it. She decided to go for broke, her voice taking on a saccharine, slightly pitying tone. "It's just so fascinating. This deep, almost primal bond. It's a story we don't often get to tell. A story of two ordinary Aussie blokes, doing something so extraordinary, all for the love of family. And the fact that you're here today, sharing it with us, allowing us to celebrate you, it’s just incredibly generous." She smiled, a final attempt to frame them within her saccharine world. It was a mistake. It gave Leo the opening he had been waiting for all along.

"Generous?" Leo said, a small, wry smile finally touching his lips. "Chloe, let's not pretend we don't all know why we're really here." He looked directly into the main camera, bypassing her completely, as if speaking to a much larger, unseen audience. "We're not here because we're generous. We're here because your network offered to pay fifty thousand dollars to the physiotherapy department at Royal Perth Hospital. We're here because the public health system is so chronically under-resourced that a single piece of vital equipment, like a new set of parallel bars for people learning to walk again, is considered a luxury item. The real 'Heartland Hero' is our physio, Brenda, who works sixty-hour weeks with worn-out equipment to help people like me stand up again. The story isn't about my brother eating pies. The story is about the fact that a man nearly has to kill himself on national television just so a hospital can get a donation that should be part of its standard annual budget."

A profound and utter silence descended on the studio. The cameraman nearest them slowly lowered his camera, his face a mixture of shock and deep respect. The young assistant stared at Leo, her mouth slightly agape. Chloe Vance looked as though she had been slapped. The professional mask was gone, replaced by a blank, bloodless expression of total defeat. She had been outmanoeuvred, her sentimental narrative hijacked and replaced with a searing, undeniable indictment of the very system that made feel-good stories like hers necessary. The transaction had been laid bare for all to see. After a long, agonising moment, she turned to the floor manager, her voice a clipped, dead thing. "I think we have everything we need," she said. "We're done here."

They walked out of the studio and into the bright, indifferent Sydney afternoon without a backward glance. No one tried to stop them, no one offered a handshake or a hollow thank you. They had fulfilled their contract, but not in the way anyone had expected. They had delivered their story, but it was a story of systemic failure, not personal triumph. As they waited for a taxi on the busy street corner, surrounded by the rush and roar of a city that didn't know or care about their private war, Baz looked at his brother. A slow, genuine grin spread across his face, the first he had felt all day. "Focal substitution?" he asked, the words a low rumble of amusement. Leo shrugged, a faint smile playing on his own lips as he adjusted the collar of his shirt. "I read a lot of pamphlets in the waiting room," he said. "You pick things up." The taxi pulled up to the curb, and they climbed in, leaving the studio and its false narratives behind them. The job was done. The parallel bars were paid for. It was time to go home.
